history: Machu Picchu is an ancient Incan citadel located in the Andes Mountains of Peru. It was built in the 15th century and abandoned during the Spanish Conquest. The citadel remained hidden until its rediscovery in 1911 by Hiram Bingham. Machu Picchu is believed to have been a royal estate or sacred religious site for the Incan emperor.
Ecological Relevance: Machu Picchu is located in a region with diverse ecosystems, including cloud forests and high-altitude grasslands. Its position on a mountain ridge provides stunning views of the surrounding landscape and offers important insights into the agricultural practices of the Incas.

timeline.Details: Construction of Machu Picchu begins during the height of the Incan Empire.
Machu Picchu is abandoned following the Spanish Conquest of the Incan Empire.
Hiram Bingham rediscovers Machu Picchu, bringing international attention to the site.
Machu Picchu is designated a UNESCO World Heritage Site, recognizing its cultural significance.
Machu Picchu is voted one of the New Seven Wonders of the World in a global poll.
Machu Picchu temporarily closes to visitors due to the COVID-19 pandemic, highlighting the need for sustainable tourism practices.
